dataset.title: Satellite tagging of Harbor Seals in Prince William Sound, Alaska: 1992 - 1999

associatedParty.organizationName: National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis

address.deliveryPoint: National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis, Unversity of California, Santa Barbara

abstract.para:
Study History: Restoration Project 01064 began in 1993 as a continuation of the initial post-spill study effort conducted as Marine Mammal Study Number 5 (Assessment of Injury to Harbor Seals in Prince William Sound, Alaska, and Adjacent Areas) in 1989 through 1991 and reclassified as Restoration Study Number 73 (Harbor Seal Restoration Study) in 1992. A final report was issued in 1994 for the combined Marine Mammal Study Number 5 and Restoration Study Number 73, entitled Assessment of Injury to Harbor Seals in Prince William Sound, Alaska, and Adjacent Areas Following the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill. Subsequently, annual reports were submitted entitled Habitat Use, Behavior, and Monitoring of Harbor Seals in Prince William Sound: 1994 Annual Report, 1995 Annual Report, 1996 Annual Report , 1997 Annual Report, 1998 Annual Report, and 1999 Annual Report . Fatty acid studies funded under Restoration Project 94320-F (Trophic Interactions of Harbor Seals in Prince William Sound) were included in the 1994 annual report for 94064. Fatty acid studies were continued and reported as part of this study for the duration of the project.
Abstract: We used aerial counts to monitor the trend in numbers of harbor seals in Prince William Sound, Alaska, following the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill. Repetitive counts were made at 25 haul-out sites during the annual molt period each year from 1990 through 1997. A generalized linear model indicated that time of day, date, and time relative to low tide significantly affected seal counts. When Poisson regression was used to adjust counts to a standardized set of survey conditions, results showed a highly significant decline of 4.6% per year. Unadjusted counts indicated a slight, but not statistically significant, decline in the number of seals. The number of harbor seals on the trend-count route in eastern and central PWS has been declining since at least 1984, with an overall population reduction of 63% through 1997. Programs to monitor long-term changes in animal population sizes should account for factors that can cause short-term variations in indices of abundance. The inclusion of such factors as covariates in models can improve the accuracy of monitoring programs.
Publications:
Adkison, M. D., T. J. Quinn II, and R. J. Small. 2003. Evaluation of the Alaska harbor seal population (Phoca vitulina) population survey: a simulation study. Marine Mammal Science 19: 764-90.
Boveng, P. L., J. L. Bengtson, D. E. Withrow, J. C. Cesarone, M. A. Simpkins, K. J. Frost, and J. J. Burns. 2003. The abundance of harbor seals in the Gulf of Alaska. Marine Mammal Science 19: 111-27.
Frost, K.J., Lowry, L.F., Ver Hoef, J.M., Iverson, S.J., Simpkins, M.A. 2005. Monitoring Habitat Use, and Trophic Interactions of Harbor Seals in Prince William Sound, Alaska. Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council Report (Project #01064, 99064, 98064, 97064, 96064, 95064, 94064, 93064, R073, MM05). Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Fairbanks, Alaska.
Frost, K. J., L. F. Lowry, and J. Ver Hoef. 1999. Monitoring the trend of harbor seals in Prince William Sound, Alaska, after the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Marine Mammal Science 15, no. 2: 494-506.
Ver Hoef, J. M., and K. J. Frost. 2003. A Bayesian hierarchical model for monitoring harbor seal changes in Prince William Sound, Alaska. Environmental and Ecological Statistics 10: 201-9.
The data here include only satellite tagging data, aerial survey data can be found under package ID: df35d.97.14 at http://evos.nceas.ucsb.edu/evos/metacat/df35d.97.14/default

Standard scientific norms for attribution and credit to the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council and any additional funding agencies should be followed when using this data.

contact.organizationName: Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Harbor Seal Research Program
Alaska Department of Fish and Game

section.title: Satellite-Linked Dive Recorder (SDR) Data
section.para: Tag information: All the satellite tags in the attached data files are known as Satellite-linked Dive Recorders (SDRs). They are the T16 model made by a company called Wildlife Computers in Seattle. The tags are not GPS-type tags and do not estimate their own position. Rather, the tag transmits a radio signal and a series of polar orbiting NOAA satellites use Doppler Effect to estimate the location of the tag from these signals. The "location quality code" (in the tables below) is derived from how many signals were received by the satellites (more signals = better accuracy). The company that does this is "CLS" and they call their system for collecting information from satellite tags the "Argos" system. Hence, you will see the word "Argos" in some of the file names.

1. The Argos position file (i.e., 1992-1999 PWS seals-Argos.csv) has all the location data for each seal. Note that these are the data in their most raw form; we are giving you the option of filtering or modeling location error as you see fit. Location quality codes are assigned to each observation. Also note that some of the tags were duty-cycled (described in greater detail below).

2. The histogram file (i.e., 1992-1999 PWS seals-Histos.csv) has the dive histograms. Tags have depth transducers that can measure depth to ~2 meters. The tags turn on and quantify depth once every 10 seconds. Unfortunately, this is too much information to transmit, so the data were reduced into histograms that cover 6 hour periods. Histogram bins (upper thresholds) are defined by the user before the tag is deployed. Once deployed, the bins cannot be altered. The dive data consists of four histogram types:

a. Maximum Depth (DiveDepth): The tag records the maximum depth during each dive. At the end of each 6 hour period, the number of dives is tallied for each depth bin. Hence, this is a count of dives that fall within each bin. For example, assume there are three bins with upper limits of 20m, 40m, and 60m. Further assume a seal makes 6 dives over the summary period, with maximum depths of: 5m, 10m, 19m, 20m, 30m, and 41m. The 20m bin would have a count of 4, the 40m bin would have a count of 1, and the 60m bin would have a count of zero. The last bin is always defined as ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Âœgreater thanÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â. In other words, if I set the tags to record dives to 250m, the last histogram bin will contain all dives deeper than 250m.
b. Dive Duration (DiveDuration): This is also a count of dives; however, the upper bin thresholds are defined by time in minutes. For example, bin thresholds might be 5 min, 10 min, 15 min, etc.

c. Time at Depth (TAD): This is the most difficult histogram to understand. The bin thresholds are defined as depth in meters. The data are presented as a "proportion of time spent in each depth bin". The values should sum to 1. What is actually going on is this: the tag "wakes up" once every 10 seconds and records if the tag is wet or dry (0 or 1). At the end of each 6 hour period, there are 2160 observations. The occurrence of zeros is used to partition the time series into dives. The number of observations in each dive is multiplied by 10 to convert the value into ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœsecondsÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â. In effect, they are assuming that a tag is wet or dry for the entire time between 10 second sampling events. Each dive is then assigned to a histogram bin. Finally, the counts are converted to proportions.

d. Twenty Minute Timelines (TwentyMinTimeline): The tag divides each 24 hour period into 20-minute intervals. If the tag is deeper than a user defined depth threshold for the majority of the 10 second sampling events during each 20 minute interval, then the value is 1, otherwise 0. This data is generally too coarse to be of much use.

3. The "SEA" file (i.e., 1992-1999PWS SEA.xlsx) contains the wet/dry (wet=1, dry=0) observations from the tags. The tags have a conductivity sensor that indicated whether the tag was dry or submerged. The conductivity sensor records when the tag is out of the water. It may give a reading of ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœdryÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â when the seal is at sea if the two poles of the sensor are both out of the water (e.g., the seal is floating with its back out of the water). This can lead to some confusion in interpreting messages sent by the tag. Often, a seal is referred to as ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Âœhauled outÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â when we really only know that its conductivity sensor was dry. To minimize this problem the tags are set so that a minimum number of transmissions must occur with the conductivity sensor dry before the unit will switch to giving the code for dry. This has been set as 10 transmissions, which with the at-sea transmission interval of 45 seconds means that the unit must be continuously out of the water for about 7 minutes. Note that "transmission" in this context is when the tag attempts to transmit, not when a transmission is received by a satellite. As such, a tag may be dry for longer than 7 minutes before the a dry transmission is received by an Argos satellite. Only one wet transmission is required for a status change to wet. Again, the seal may be in the water for some time before a transmission is successfully received by a satellite and the status is changed to wet. As such, continuously dry status readings reliably indicate when a seal is hauled out, but how to classify the periods between wet and dry readings is unclear.

Tag settings and bin definitions can be foind on attached table (tagSettings.csv). Note that the upper limits of the bins (i.e., the bin thresholds) have changed through time. Also note that the clock onboard the tags were offset such that the histogram periods (6 hour intervals) correspond to local sun time. Hence, the histogram times correspond to morning (03:01 - 09:00), day (09:01-15:00), afternoon (15:01-21:00), and night (21:01-03:00). The Argos positions are given in GMT. Hence, to line up the dive intervals with the Argos locations, you must subtract 13 or 14 hours from the histogram times.

methodStep.instrumentation: Satellite-linked Dive Recorders (SDRs), model T16, by 'Wildlife Computers'

section.title: Trend Analysis
section.para: A linear regression model was fitted to the adjusted yearly count estimates for 1990-1997. This model assumes constant amount of change per year. We also considered a model on the log-scale, where the rate of change is constant. Again, we used a generalized linear model (McCullagh and Nelder 1989) with a log link function and a Poisson distribution to model trend through time. This is also called Poisson regression. Linear and Poisson regressions were also fitted to the unadjusted counts.

This analysis was complicated because we first adjusted yearly counts for each site to a standardized date, time of day, and time relative to low tide, then summed over sites to get a yearly index, and then used the index in a trend regression analysis. Under these circumstances it is difficult to pass the uncertainty associated with adjusting the counts to the trend analysis. Therefore, we used bootstrap methods (Efron and Tibshirani 1993, Manly 1997) for the whole procedure. We resampled with replacement from the daily flights for each year, with the number of resamples equal to the actual number of flights for that year. After obtaining the bootstrap sample, we used the generalized linear model to re-estimate parameters, adjusted the counts based on the bootstrap parameter estimates, and then did both linear and Poisson regression trend estimation on the bootstrap samples. The trend parameters from the bootstrap appeared symmetrically distributed and centered on the original parameter estimate. Bootstrapping the whole procedure was quite computer-intensive and only 200 resampled estimates were obtained, so we used the standard bootstrap method (Manly 1997) and if 0 was contained in the interval, there was little evidence of trend for the stated alpha-level. Bootstrapping was used to estimate variance of the unadjusted counts by resampling from the actual count values for each site in each year. (from Frost, K. J., L. F. Lowry, and J. Ver Hoef. 1999. Monitoring the trend of harbor seals in Prince William Sound, Alaska, after the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Marine Mammal Science 15, no. 2: 494-506.)

section.title: Bayesian Hierarchical Model
section.para: see publication Ver Hoef, J. M., and K. J. Frost. 2003. A Bayesian hierarchical model for monitoring harbor seal changes in Prince William Sound, Alaska. Environmental and Ecological Statistics 10: 201-9.

project.title: Monitoring, Habitat Use, and Trophic Interactions of Harbor Seals in PWS, Alaska

funding.para: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council projects 01064, 99064, 98064, 97064, 96064, 95064, 94064, 93064, R073, MM05

attribute.attributeDefinition: A unique animal I.D. assigned by the user (ADF&G in this case). It is made up of a concatenation of ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœPVÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â for Phoca vitulina (harbor seal), two numbers for the year of capture (e.g. 96 for the year 1996), 2-3 letters indicating the capture location (e.g. PWS for Prince William Sound), and lastly, the number assigned to the animal (1, 2, 3ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â¦ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â¦25, etc.).
Unknown ID of some sort only found in this file. Please use the deployedID as the unique animal identifier as it is consistent throughout all spreadsheets.
Argos Platform Transmitter Terminal identifier. Note that the PTTs are reused through time. You have to match this up with the Deploy ID number to identify individuals.
Date of message reception in UTC/GMT. If the histogram was received multiple times, this will be the date and time of the latest reception.
Date of message reception in UTC/GMT. If the histogram was received multiple times, this will be the date and time of the latest reception.
Time formatted to hh:mm:ss

"0" means the SDR was at the "on land" rate; "1" means the SDR was at the "at sea" rate. The assumption is that when the sensor indicated wet (at sea) the seal was at sea, and when it indicated dry (on land) the seal was on land.

codeDefinition.definition: SDR on land
SDR at sea

attribute.attributeDefinition: A unique animal I.D. assigned by the user (ADF&G in this case). It is made up of a concatenation of ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœPVÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â for Phoca vitulina (harbor seal), two numbers for the year of capture (e.g. 96 for the year 1996), 2-3 letters indicating the capture location (e.g. PWS for Prince William Sound), and lastly, the number assigned to the animal (1, 2, 3ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â¦ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â¦25, etc.).
Argos Platform Transmitter Terminal identifier. Note that the PTTs are reused through time. You have to match this up with the Deploy ID number.
Wildlife Computers instrument family. In this file, the only instrument family is ST16.

codeDefinition.definition: Wildlife Computers ST16 instrument family

attribute.attributeDefinition: Type of ARGOS record, either DS or DI. The DS record contains the data that the tag transmitted along with the Argos calculated position, if a position could be calculated. The DI record contains the results of the Argos calculated positions.

codeDefinition.definition: record contains the data that the tag transmitted along with the Argos calculated position
record contains the results of the Argos calculated positions

attribute.attributeDefinition: Number of messages received from the PPT for the satellite pass.
The number of identical messages received for the satellite pass. A value of ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Âœ1ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â means the original plus one duplicate was received.

codeDefinition.definition: No duplicates, original only
No duplicate record
Original plus one duplicate received

attribute.attributeDefinition: The number of corrupt messages in the given satellite pass.
The average inter-message interval in seconds of all received messages for the given satellite pass
The minimum inter-message interval in seconds among received messages for a satellite pass
Date and time of message reception in UTC/GMT. It is not corrected for clock error or drift.
Name of the Argos satellite that received the message

Location class assigned by Argos for the computed position. Location classes are based on satellite/transmitter geometry during satellite pass, number of messages received during the pass, and transmitter frequency stability.

codeDefinition.definition: No estimate of accuracy available because only 3 messages were received
No estimate of accuracy available because only 2 messages were received
True position is between 350m and 1000m of reported location
True position is more than 1000m from reported location
True position is within 150m and 350m of reported location
True position is within 150m of reported location
The calculated was rejected for some reason

attribute.attributeDefinition: Latitude in Decimal degrees, computed by Argos.
Longitude in decimal degrees, calculated by Argos.
Argos DI messages contain a second latitude value since their location algorithm can generate two possible positions. This is the second latitude value.
Argos DI messages contain a second longitude value since their location algorithm can generate two possible positions. This is the second longitude value.
Argos-supplied value which gives transmitter frequency information. It should be interpreted as a two digit value in the form of XY whose meanings are:

codeDefinition.definition: No calculation of residual frequency error (fewer than four messages received)
Unsatisfactory convergence of calculation
Unsatisfactory convergence of calculation
Unsatisfactory convergence of calculation
Residual frequency error > 1.5 Hz
0.15 Hz < residual frequency error < 1.5 Hz
Residual frequency error < 0.15 Hz
No check on transmit frequency drift, as the two results are more than 12 hours apart.
Frequency discrepancy > 400 Hz Probably due to transmit frequency discrepancy, change of oscillator, etc.
Previous location is less than 1/2 hour old. Frequency discrepancy > 30 Hz, i.e. F/F (over 10 min) >2.5 E-8
Frequency drift > 4 Hz/minute, i.e. F/F (10 min) > 1.10-7
Frequency drift < 4 Hz/minute, i.e. F/F (10 min) < 1.10-7
Frequency drift < 2 Hz/minute, i.e. F/F (10 min) < 5. 10-8
Frequency drift < 1 Hz/minute, i.e. F/F (10 min) < 2.5. 10-8
Frequency drift < 0.4 Hz/minute, i.e. F/F (10 min) < 1.10-8
Frequency drift < 0.2 Hz/minute, i.e. F/F (10 min) < 5.10-9

attribute.attributeDefinition: Time elapsed between the first and last message received by the transmitter.
Calculated frequency of the transmitter.
The best received signal strength (dB) during the satellite pass

dataTable.entityDescription: Dive histogram data: dive duration, depth, time at depth

attribute.attributeDefinition: A unique animal I.D. assigned by the researchers. attribute.attributeDefinition: Type of information contained in the ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœBinÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â columns. Possible values include: DiveDepth, DiveDuration, TAD, TwentyMin Timeline.

codeDefinition.definition: Time at depth
Dive depth
Dive duration
Twenty minute timeline

attribute.attributeDefinition: The date and time associated with the row. In the case of histograms, this is the start of the histogram period. This is recorded in local time. See 'tagSetDef.csv' for the local time corresponding to 00h UTC/GMT.
The number of seconds of error in the Date field. Time Offset + Date = Real World Time If this field is blank, no clock correction information is available.
The total number of times this particular data item was received, verified, and successfully decoded.

Location class assigned by Argos for the computed position. Location classes are based on satellite/transmitter geometry during satellite pass, number of messages received during the pass, and transmitter frequency stability.

codeDefinition.definition: True position is more than 1000m from reported location
No estimate of accuracy available because only 3 messages were received
No estimate of accuracy available because only 2 messages were received

True position is within 150m and 350m of reported location

No record

attribute.attributeDefinition: Latitude in decimal degrees
Longitude in decimal degrees.
The number of columns of information for this particular data item; the data is contained in the following ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœBinÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â columns.
The sum total of the data in each bin on the current row.

This is the year that the tag was deployed. Sometimes the year/season is listed more than once because tags with different settings were deployed in the same season.
This is the season that the tag was deployed. Sometimes the year/season is listed more than once because tags with different settings were deployed in the same season.
The PTTs deployed during that year/season that share the same tag settings. Note that the PTTs are reused through time. You have to match this up with the Deploy ID
The number of PTTs listed in the row that all share the same settings.
The number of bins that will collect histogram data.

attribute.attributeLabel: Upper limits of maximum depth histogram bins
attribute.attributeDefinition: Maximum depth for each histogram bin. This is in meters.

attribute.attributeLabel: Upper limits of TAD histogram bins
attribute.attributeDefinition: Upper limits of TAD histogram bins, collected in Minutes

attribute.attributeLabel: Upper limits of dive-duration histogram bins
attribute.attributeDefinition: Upper limits of dive-duration histogram bins collected in minutes.

Tags are programmed for what days they will transmit. To extend the battery life, some tags are programmed to transmit less often (e.g. every other day instead of every day). ÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚ÂœNo dutyÃƒÂƒÃ‚Â¢ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â€ÃƒÂ‚Ã‚Â means the tag is set to transmit every day.
The hours the tag is set to transmit (0-23). This is in GMT/UTC.

attribute.attributeLabel: Local time corresponding to 00h GMT/UTC (0-23 hours)
attribute.attributeDefinition: he tag is programmed with a GMT offset by the user. The bin data is stored according to true local time based on the GMT offset.
